title: Navigating Policy and Progress: The State of the U.S. Healthcare Industry
subtitle: Healthcare + Legislature
theme: Healthcare policy, regulation, and operational impact
executiveSummary: The U.S. healthcare system in 2025 is undergoing seismic transformation. Fueled by policy turbulence, economic pressure, and an accelerating digital landscape, healthcare stakeholders are balancing innovation with compliance, efficiency with accessibility, and regulation with operational practicality. This whitepaper is based on expert insights shared during a live webinar, hosted by ImagineSoftware, welcoming Matt Reiter, Director of Government Affairs, and Brad Lund, Executive Director, of the Healthcare Business Management Association (HBMA). Their expert insights outline how government policy, regulation, and emerging trends such as AI and cybersecurity are shaping the operational realities of the revenue cycle management (RCM) industry and, more broadly, the American healthcare ecosystem.

sections.sectionTitle: The Role of RCM in a Policy-Driven System
sections.content: RCM companies serve as the operational engine behind healthcare delivery. While legislation often targets "providers," the burden of implementation frequently falls to administrative and operational entities. These companies ensure compliance with complex regulations, navigate shifting payer landscapes, and translate policy into practice. As Matt Reiter notes, advocacy in healthcare is a two-way street: not just lobbying for change but being a resource to government in crafting workable solutions.

sections.sectionTitle: Legislative Update: One Big Beautiful Bill Act (H.R.1)
sections.content: Passed via budget reconciliation, H.R.1 reshaped tax policy and included notable healthcare provisions.
keyPoints: 2.5% increase in Medicare Physician Payments in 2026 (offsetting 2025 cut)
Exclusion of a long-fought-for annual inflationary update to Medicare rates
Major Medicaid eligibility changes starting in 2027, with potential loss of coverage for up to 10 million individuals
Expiration of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidy enhancements by year-end

sections.sectionTitle: Administrative Realignment and Ideological Shifts
sections.content: Under Secretary Robert F. Kennedy and the "Make America Healthy Again" (MAHA) philosophy, the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is pursuing aggressive reorganization. The movement frames the existing system as enabling poor health outcomes due to entrenched government and industry alliances. Reforms under consideration include decoupling Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) from the American Medical Association’s (AMA) RUC process and streamlining agencies to improve emergency response and cybersecurity.

sections.sectionTitle: Regulation in Action: The No Surprises Act
sections.content: A prime example of legislative intent diverging from regulatory implementation, the No Surprises Act’s IDR (Independent Dispute Resolution) process was initially skewed to favor median in-network rates. Legal challenges corrected the bias, but operational confusion persists. Even for providers not engaging in IDR, the act’s effects on contract negotiations are profound, pushing rates downward and increasing payer leverage.

sections.sectionTitle: Artificial Intelligence: Promise Amidst Policy Paralysis
sections.content: AI adoption in administrative healthcare is nascent but growing. While clinical uses dominate headlines, administrative applications such as automated coding, appeal letters, prior authorization, and eligibility checks are increasingly relevant. Federal AI policy, however, remains immature. Despite the FDA’s embrace of AI for internal use, Congress removed a provision blocking state-level AI restrictions from H.R.1, leaving a regulatory vacuum.

sections.sectionTitle: Looking Ahead: Congressional Motivations and Industry Implications
sections.content: Ultimately, federal policymakers are driven by cost containment. With Medicare and Medicaid consuming over half of the federal budget, efforts to curb spending through rate caps, audits, eligibility cuts, or regulatory enforcement are likely to intensify. Both providers and billing organizations must understand these drivers and seek technology partners that effectively adapt and advocate.

keyTakeaways: The healthcare industry in 2025 is defined by paradox: policy ambition meets operational complexity, regulatory reform collides with real-world implementation, and innovation races ahead of oversight. The medical billing industry sits at the intersection of policy and practice, and must remain engaged, informed, and proactive to shape outcomes.

Traditional AI and RPA tools stop short of completing these tasks end-to-end because they rely on static rules or human-triggered actions. Agentic AI changes that. By equipping intelligent agents with goals, tools, and the ability to act autonomously within ImagineSoftware’s ImagineCo-Pilot® platform, revenue cycle teams can now bridge the gap between recommendation and resolution. These self-directed systems don’t just suggest what should be done – they do it. This white paper explores how Agentic AI within ImagineCo-Pilot completes the “last mile” of RCM automation, delivering measurable efficiency, accuracy, and financial return.

sections.sectionTitle: The Automation Gap in Healthcare RCM
sections.content: Despite widespread adoption of AI-assisted analytics and robotic process automation (RPA), revenue cycle operations remain fragmented. Traditional AI excels at analysis, identifying patterns, predicting denials, surfacing insights. RPA, meanwhile, is good at repetition, executing the same sequence of keystrokes over and over. But the RCM environment is dynamic. Payer rules, web layouts, and data formats constantly change. Rule-based bots break, and predictive AI stops at recommendation. The result? The “last mile” of automation, turning insight into completed work, remains a human burden.
keyPoints: Denial management teams still key appeal letters manually.
Cash posters reconcile duplicate payments by hand.
Portal staff log into payer sites daily to check claim status.

sections.sectionTitle: Enter Agentic AI: The Evolution of Intelligent Automation
sections.content: Agentic AI represents a new class of autonomous, goal-oriented systems that can make decisions, adapt, and act within defined parameters. Instead of waiting for a prompt or instruction, an agent understands its objective – for example, “keep claims current and compliant” – and determines the steps needed to achieve it. Agentic AI functions as an active participant in the revenue cycle, continuously learning from outcomes and coordinating with other agents (a “swarm”) to achieve broader goals such as reducing denials or accelerating cash.
keyPoints: Proactive – Pursues defined goals
Executes decisions and actions
Learns and adapts over time
Uses integrated tools to reach beyond

sections.sectionTitle: Completing the Last Mile: End-to-End Task Automation
sections.content: With agentic AI, the workflow no longer stops at “what to do” – it continues through doing it. Before Agentic AI, AI predicts a denial or recommends a correction, and the user reviews the alert, navigates to the account, and performs the fix. After Agentic AI, the agent identifies the issue, determines the fix, executes the actions, and verifies success. The user is notified only when exceptions require human approval. This shift moves RCM automation from advisory to actionable, freeing staff for higher-value work such as resolving complex denials and payer negotiations.

sections.content: Autonomous systems require trust, and ImagineCo-Pilot delivers it through strong governance. Agents operate within defined boundaries; certain actions remain prohibited. Only authorized users can trigger sensitive actions through ImagineCo-Pilot’s chat interface. Every step, decision, and data change is logged and viewable in ImagineOne. When an agent cannot safely complete a step, it automatically routes the task for review.

title: The True Cost of Revenue Leakage in Anesthesiology Practices
subtitle: How Technology, Data, and Insight Protect Profitability in a Complex Billing Environment
theme: Anesthesiology revenue cycle management and revenue leakage prevention
executiveSummary: In anesthesiology, every minute counts - both in the operating room and on the balance sheet. Yet for many anesthesia groups, hidden inefficiencies in the revenue cycle quietly drain hundreds of thousands of dollars each year. From incomplete data capture to payer-specific coding errors and slow claim follow-up, revenue leakage is a silent but solvable problem. This white paper explores how anesthesia practice leaders can identify and quantify revenue leakage, where the most common breakdowns occur, and how technology platforms like ImagineOne® empower practices to recover lost revenue, improve transparency, and sustain financial strength.

sections.sectionTitle: The Financial Reality of Revenue Leakage
sections.content: Every anesthesia practice feels the pressure of rising costs, tighter reimbursement, and increased administrative complexity. But while most leaders focus on production and staffing efficiency, few have clear visibility into revenue leakage - the preventable loss of earned income due to process inefficiencies or billing errors.

sections.sectionTitle: What Is Revenue Leakage?
sections.content: Revenue leakage occurs when services are performed and documented, but not fully reimbursed due to data gaps, coding inconsistencies, or missed follow-up. In anesthesiology, where billing depends on precise time units, modifiers, and payer-specific rules, the risk is especially high.

sections.sectionTitle: Why It’s Often Invisible
sections.content: Data originates in the OR, often on paper or disparate systems not integrated with billing software. Manual processes rely on institutional “tribal knowledge” that doesn’t scale. Denials are treated reactively, not proactively analyzed for root causes.

sections.sectionTitle: The Financial Impact of Leakage
sections.content: An anesthesia group performing 20,000 cases annually with an average allowed reimbursement of $350 per case could lose 3–5% of revenue due to leakage. Over time, these inefficiencies accumulate - and even a small percentage of missed or underpaid claims can erode margins significantly.
keyPoints: 3% leakage = $210,000 lost annually
5% leakage = $350,000 lost annually
That’s the financial equivalent of an additional provider or new contract site - silently slipping away each year.

sections.sectionTitle: Financial Impact Modeling: Quantifying What’s Missing
sections.content: Understanding the magnitude of revenue leakage is the first step toward addressing it. Financial impact modeling combines billing data, payment trends, and process metrics to pinpoint where and how revenue loss occurs.
keyPoints: Charge Capture Accuracy – Are all anesthesia time units and modifiers billed?
Denial Frequency and Root Causes – Which payers, codes, or sites generate the most denials?
Days to Bill and Collect – How long between case completion and claim submission/payment?
Underpayments – Are contracted rates being met, or are small variances accumulating?

sections.sectionTitle: Common Failure Points in the Anesthesia Revenue Cycle
sections.content: Anesthesia billing has unique complexities - time-based units, concurrency rules, physical status modifiers, and site-specific requirements. These create multiple opportunities for leakage if processes are not standardized or automated.
keyPoints: Incomplete or delayed data capture
Coding and modifier errors
Denial management gaps
Reporting blind spots

sections.sectionTitle: Benchmarks and KPIs Every Anesthesia Leader Should Track
sections.content: Visibility is the foundation of control. Anesthesia leaders who track key performance indicators (KPIs) can spot early warning signs of leakage and make data-backed decisions to improve cash flow.
keyPoints: % of cases billed within 48 hours
First-pass clean claim rate
Denial rate by payer
Days in A/R (target < 35)
% of expected reimbursement received
Claims processed per FTE
% of claims touched manually
quotes: Clean claim rates above 95% correlate with significant cash acceleration.
Reducing average billing lag by just two days can improve annual cash flow by tens of thousands of dollars.
Groups using predictive denial analysis report fewer repeat denials and faster secondary collections.

keyPoints: Pre-Service to Zero Balance
AI-Powered Automation
Configurable Workflows
Advanced Analytics
quotes: ImagineOne gives anesthesia leaders what they’ve always needed, a single system that connects every dollar earned to every dollar collected.

sections.sectionTitle: The Leadership Imperative: From Reaction to Prevention
sections.content: Revenue leakage isn’t just an operational issue - it’s a leadership issue. As anesthesia groups face thinner margins and rising administrative demands, the ability to measure, predict, and prevent loss becomes a strategic differentiator.
keyPoints: Predictable cash flow and cleaner audits

Confidence in data-driven decisions

keyTakeaways: The cost of revenue leakage isn’t just lost cash, it’s lost confidence. With ImagineSoftware, anesthesia leaders gain both back.

title: Where Oncology Practices Are Losing the Most Money: And How Leaders Can Regain Control
subtitle: Oncology + RCM
theme: Oncology revenue cycle risk, revenue loss, and financial resilience
executiveSummary: Oncology practices operate in one of the most financially complex environments in healthcare. High-cost drugs, evolving payer rules, prior authorization requirements, and chronic staffing shortages have turned revenue cycle management (RCM) into a strategic risk area - not just an operational function. Yet many oncology practices continue to lose significant revenue quietly and consistently, without clear visibility into where or why it’s happening. This white paper examines the three primary sources of revenue loss in oncology RCM: Drug underpayments, Denials and write-offs, and Lack of payer performance visibility. It also explores how modern oncology leaders are using automation, analytics, and centralized intelligence, specifically through ImagineOne®, to uncover hidden losses, reduce risk, and build financial resilience.

sections.sectionTitle: Why Oncology Revenue Cycle Management is Uniquely Vulnerable
sections.content: Oncology practices operate in one of the most financially complex reimbursement environments in healthcare. High-cost drugs, evolving treatment protocols, and inconsistent payer behavior create significant revenue risk, even for well-managed organizations.
keyPoints: Extremely high-cost drugs and biologics
Complex coding and billing requirements
Payer-specific reimbursement methodologies
Tight margins that leave little room for error

sections.sectionTitle: Drug Underpayments: The Largest and Least Visible Revenue Leak
sections.content: Drug claims are often partially paid, not denied. Because payment is received, these claims frequently bypass traditional denial workflows. Common causes include incorrect payer fee schedules, contract misinterpretation, units or modifiers paid incorrectly, payer noncompliance with negotiated rates, and policy changes not reflected in internal systems. Manual review is rarely effective due to claim volume and complexity.
keyPoints: Practices may lose hundreds of thousands to millions annually in drug underpayments alone.
Recovery windows close before issues are discovered.

sections.sectionTitle: Denials and Write-Offs: The Cost of Reactivity
sections.content: Oncology practices face elevated denial risk due to prior authorization complexity, medical necessity disputes, coding and documentation variability, and payer policy inconsistency. Many organizations focus on appealing denials after the fact, rather than preventing them.
keyPoints: Increased days in A/R
Delayed or lost cash flow
Staff time diverted to rework
Growing write-offs due to appeal fatigue or missed deadlines

sections.sectionTitle: Lack of Payer Visibility: Managing Blindfolded
sections.content: Many oncology leaders lack clear answers to fundamental questions about payer behavior and reimbursement accuracy. Traditional reports often provide lagging, high-level data, not actionable intelligence.
keyPoints: Which payers underpay the most?
Which contracts are consistently noncompliant?
Where are denial trends worsening?
Which issues are isolated vs. systemic?

keyPoints: Fragmentation creates blind spots

title: The Economics of the No Surprises Act: Why 90% of Eligible Claims Are Being Left on the Table
subtitle: IDR + RCM
theme: Independent Dispute Resolution economics and revenue recovery
executiveSummary: The No Surprises Act (NSA) reshaped the landscape of reimbursement. Patients are now shielded from unexpected out-of-network bills, but providers face a new challenge: securing fair payment from payers. To address this, Congress created Independent Dispute Resolution (IDR) — an arbitration mechanism designed to resolve disputes between providers and insurers. IDR offers providers the ability to secure fairer reimbursement, often several times higher than the initial payer offer. Yet most providers are not taking advantage. Only about 10% of eligible claims are pursued through IDR. That means 90% of claims — billions of dollars in potential revenue — are left on the table each year. This white paper explores the economics of underutilizing IDR, quantifies the revenue impact, and provides a framework for providers to build IDR into their revenue cycle strategy.

sections.sectionTitle: NSA and IDR at a Glance
sections.content: The No Surprises Act, enacted in 2022, prohibits balance billing for emergency services at out-of-network facilities, out-of-network care delivered at in-network hospitals, and ancillary services like anesthesia, radiology, and pathology, when patients cannot reasonably choose their provider. The Act protects patients, but leaves providers to resolve payment disputes with insurers. To do so, it created the Independent Dispute Resolution (IDR) process, where an independent arbiter decides between the provider’s proposed payment and the payer’s.
keyPoints: Open Negotiation: Informal discussions between provider and payer (30 business days).
Formal IDR Filing: Submission of claims, documentation, and fees to CMS and an IDR entity.
Arbiter Decision: A third-party arbiter rules in favor of either the provider’s or the payer’s offer.
Payment & Collections: Payer must issue payment, typically within 30 days (though delays are common).
quotes: The intent is clear: Protect patients while ensuring providers are fairly reimbursed.

sections.sectionTitle: The Utilization Gap
sections.content: Despite the opportunity, IDR is dramatically underutilized. Only 10% of eligible claims are pursued. 90% are abandoned, defaulting to inadequate payer reimbursement.
keyPoints: Administrative Complexity: Dozens of forms, strict deadlines, and a 6+ month timeline.
Staffing Constraints: Most billing teams lack resources to manage the process.
Uncertainty about ROI: Providers are unsure if the effort will pay off.
Cash Flow Pressures: Awards can take months to materialize.
quotes: The result is billions of dollars left uncollected each year.

sections.sectionTitle: The Financial Impact of Underutilization
sections.content: The numbers tell a stark story.
keyPoints: Without IDR: Commercial out-of-network claims average 1–1.5x Medicare.
With IDR: Providers average 3–6x Medicare, with many specialties trending higher.
Lost opportunity: For hospital-based specialties, this translates into millions of dollars annually in unrecovered reimbursement.

sections.sectionTitle: Case Example: What’s Being Left Behind
sections.content: Consider a hypothetical emergency medicine group: 50,000 annual NSA-eligible claims. Average payer reimbursement without IDR: 1.5x Medicare. Average reimbursement with IDR: 6x Medicare. The math is clear: providers that underutilize IDR are walking away from substantial revenue.
keyPoints: If the group pursues only 10% of claims: Incremental revenue: ~$5 million.
If they pursue 50% of claims: Incremental revenue: ~$25 million.

sections.sectionTitle: ROI Framework for Providers
sections.content: To make informed decisions, providers should apply a structured ROI framework to IDR.
keyPoints: Calculate Eligible Claim Volume: Identify the number of claims that fall under NSA eligibility rules.
Estimate Current Reimbursement: Use your baseline average (typically 1–1.5x Medicare).
Project IDR Reimbursement: Apply historical IDR benchmarks (3–6x Medicare).
Factor in Costs: Account for filing fees, staff time, or vendor contingency fees.
Calculate ROI: Subtract costs from incremental revenue.
Providers consistently see positive ROI when IDR is pursued strategically.

sections.sectionTitle: Operational Considerations
sections.content: Pursuing IDR at scale requires more than just eligibility screening and filing claims, it requires an operational strategy.
keyPoints: The average IDR cycle is six months, with payment delays often extending an additional three months.
Each case involves strict timelines, multiple filings, and government submission requirements.
Submitting ineligible claims risks wasted resources, unfavorable outcomes, and even legal challenges.
Providers must decide whether to manage IDR internally or partner with a specialized vendor.

sections.sectionTitle: The Broader Economic Implications
sections.content: The underutilization of IDR is not just a provider issue, it’s a systemic one.
keyPoints: Billions left on the table weaken provider margins, leading to staffing cuts and financial instability.
Payers face little accountability when providers do not engage in IDR, reinforcing unfair reimbursement practices.
Greater IDR participation would rebalance payer-provider dynamics and pressure payers to make fairer initial offers.
quotes: In short: failing to leverage IDR harms not just individual providers, but the healthcare system as a whole.

sections.sectionTitle: Turning Compliance Into Opportunity
sections.content: The No Surprises Act permanently changed the reimbursement landscape. While patients are protected, providers must take action to secure fair compensation. Independent Dispute Resolution is the path to that fair payment, yet 90% of eligible claims go unpursued. The economics are clear: pursuing IDR can multiply reimbursement, strengthen revenue cycles, and improve long-term financial stability.
keyPoints: By embedding IDR into the revenue cycle, providers transform compliance into opportunity.
With the right workflows, technology, and partners, IDR can shift from a burdensome process to a sustainable growth engine.

title: WISeR Wisdom: What Orthopedics & Radiology Leaders Need to Know
subtitle: Healthcare + Prior Authorization
theme: CMS WISeR program, prior authorization reform, and operational readiness
executiveSummary: In January 2026, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) will implement a new prior authorization initiative called WISeR (Wasteful and Inappropriate Service Reduction). The program will launch in six states, Texas, Oklahoma, Arizona, Washington, Ohio, and New Jersey; with the potential for broader national expansion in the future. WISeR is not just another regulatory update, it’s a paradigm shift in how outpatient procedures for Medicare patients are authorized and reimbursed. High-volume services, including many common orthopedic and radiology interventions, will soon require mandatory, pre-service approval. This white paper outlines: The objectives and scope of WISeR; The implications for orthopedic and radiology practices; The risks of continuing with manual prior authorization processes; How ImagineSoftware helps future-proof your workflows with scalable, intelligent automation.

sections.sectionTitle: Understanding the CMS WISeR Program
sections.content: WISeR stands for Wasteful and Inappropriate Service Reduction, a CMS-led initiative designed to reduce unnecessary services, improve the cost-effectiveness of Medicare, test new ways to streamline administrative burden while increasing oversight of high-cost outpatient care, standardize the prior authorization process across providers and payers, preemptively reduce improper payments by requiring prior authorization for selected services, gather data on how prior authorization impacts utilization, cost, and patient outcomes, encourage provider adoption of digital health solutions and automation, and test the feasibility of centralized oversight models before national rollout.

sections.sectionTitle: Program Scope and Pilot Design
sections.content: It builds on lessons learned from prior CMS models (like the Medicare Prior Authorization Model for Certain Hospital Outpatient Department Services) and targets specific high-volume, high-cost procedures. The WISeR pilot will run in six states, applying to Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries receiving care at hospital outpatient departments (HOPDs), ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs), and physician group practices.

sections.sectionTitle: Why Orthopedics and Radiology
sections.content: While CMS is still finalizing the exact CPT code list, early indications show WISeR will apply to arthroscopic knee procedures (meniscectomies, ligament repairs), spinal fusions and decompressions, neurostimulator implants, advanced diagnostic imaging (MRI, CT, PET), interventional radiology (kyphoplasty, ablations), and image-guided pain management (epidural injections). These procedures are routinely scheduled by orthopedists and radiologists, and they’ll soon be flagged for prior authorization every time for Medicare patients in WISeR states.
keyPoints: Represent significant Medicare spend
Are prone to overuse or variation in clinical necessity
Often lack clear documentation justifying medical need in current workflows

sections.sectionTitle: Why Prior Authorization Must Be Centralized and Automated
sections.content: Most practices today use fax-based workflows, depend on manual payer lookups, rely on email, spreadsheets, or sticky notes to track authorization status, and face delays in scheduling, high denial rates, and staff burnout. WISeR introduces more than administrative tasks. It exposes underlying inefficiencies in how many practices handle payer requirements. This model may have survived until now—but it cannot scale under WISeR.

sections.sectionTitle: WISeR as a Strategic Inflection Point
sections.content: WISeR is more than a regulation, it’s an opportunity to modernize. Organizations that proactively adopt technology and redesign processes will increase throughput without adding staff, improve financial performance by reducing denials, accelerate care delivery by eliminating PA delays, and enhance patient satisfaction through faster scheduling and fewer disruptions. Those who wait until January 2026 to adapt risk compliance failures, missed revenue opportunities, and reputational damage from long delays or coverage confusion.

sections.sectionTitle: Next Steps: A Readiness Roadmap
sections.content: Review your current PA workflows, identify pain points and manual steps, audit denial trends for PA-related issues, identify service lines that fall under WISeR, map integration points with your PM and EHR systems, engage stakeholders across billing, scheduling, clinical ops, and IT, roll out automation in a pilot environment, monitor key metrics (approval timelines, denial rates), train staff and optimize roles around the new model, scale to all relevant services and locations, use analytics and reporting to continuously improve, and prepare for potential WISeR national expansion in future phases.
keyPoints: Assess
Plan
Implement
Expand

keyTakeaways: WISeR is a wake-up call. The healthcare system is shifting, toward greater oversight, tighter margins, and more pressure to deliver seamless care. WISeR reflects all of that. It’s not just a CMS pilot; it’s a preview of what’s to come. Now is the time to build the foundation you’ll need for the future.
